WRITING.TITLE: Merging multiple columns into a single row, based on duplicate text?
WRITING.TEXT:
I'm a bit out of my Excel-depth on this one - and was hoping Reddit might be able to help. I'm attempting to merge 11 separate data sets (in this case, lists of 'best movies') - into a weighted masterlist without duplicates.
There are over 2,500 lines total, but only half of those are unique entries. I can't really describe it well, so [here's what I have now](http://i.imgur.com/J2C6nt2.png) - and [what I'm trying to create](http://i.imgur.com/nYZ4bT9.png).
Not sure if there's any quick formula to solve this, but perhaps a macro or some complicated if/and equation? Hopefully you can point me in the right direction. Thanks, all.
Machete Order + TPM is just "Flashback Order", FYI :-)
Hope it helped!

"To display one overlay ad, the content clip must be 30 seconds or longer."
You might be able to monetize short content, but ads won't actually display, so yeah, you can't effectively monetize short content.

Is that true?
No. 100% false, sorry. (Who keeps perpetuating this myth?)

Yes, appeal. You still have a chance to counter-notify after a failure at this second-step anyway. I've appealed and won over 100 separate video claims -for more info, I recommend you watch this video on Content ID, https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=slgldWAsB0M

You can't monetize content shorter than 30 seconds. https://support.google.com/adsense/answer/1706015?hl=en
/thread

Binoculars are good. Bring spare water bottle caps (since most venues don't let you have them.) Find a set list of the most recent show, and bring it with you - even if you don't want to "spoil" the songs, it's very helpful to follow along when you don't recognize them all. Leave during the last song to avoid traffic. And never wear a shirt of the band you're going to see.
:-)

Surprisingly, no! (Although that was a decidedly epic performance). His top three are:
1. Helsinki, Finland - July 31, 2012: **4 hours 36 minutes** *(includes a 30 min acoustic pre-show set)* 2. Philadelphia, PA - September 7, 2016: **4 hours 4 minutes** 3. Foxborough, MA - September 14, 2016: **4 hours, 3 minutes**
I've been to 82 big-name concerts. Bruce's show this fall at Gillette was easily the greatest I've ever seen (including 9 other shows of his I've seen).
A real highlight of my music-life, seeing one of Springsteen's 4-hour shows. He's come close MANY times, but has actually only crossed the 240-minute barrier on three occasions.

How so? And by what? It seems, in your own ignorance, you're confusing 'informed' with 'bias. Not the same thing.
Your disclosure doesn't automatically recuse the conflict though, **it still exists**. And, at the very least, your opinion on MCNs is inherently biased.

A big part of it is, yes. Overtime YouTube's algorithms handicap older channels. It's a bit like rust... every time a viewer leaves/unscribes, it hurts the channel's reputation, so to speak. And if you've been doing this for almost 11 years like I have, that rust begins to build up to a point where only 5% of your audience watches, despite having over 850,000 subs.

There were a bunch of great ideas in this little poll/contest thing they ran, and I believe a number of them have come to pass. I believe transparent annotations were a suggestion that was added soon after. But I honestly don't remember many others.

In 2010, they ran an "idea" board, where users could vote on the best suggestions, and the top results would be developed.
The "video replace" feature, which I submitted, was #1. No updates on that since :-(
Anything north of 5% is pretty good, honestly. Older channels suffer more from subscriber-burn and lower-retention, so if you're newer, what you're at now isn't awful.

You can't.
I've been requesting a "video-replace" feature to YouTube's dev-team since 2008. Who knows if they'll ever actually add it.

The great thing about words, and their respective definitions is that they don't really care what they mean "to you" :-)
* ad hominem
*(of an argument or reaction) directed against a person rather than the position they are maintaining.*
It **WAS** an ad hominem attack. Irrelevant to the conversation, and uncalled for it. Let's move on.
*why is there such a divide over people who see value in networks and those who don't?*
I don't think there is. SugiStyle is personally, and financially benefiting from his article thanks to his many referral links. **He sees a "value" in MCNs because they make him money when OTHERS sign-up.** Unfortunately, he's too stupid to recuse himself of this obvious conflict of interest.
*And I'd like to ask, is there any value to joining a network today?*
Yes, certainly - but as I've argued many times on this SubReddit and others - the 'value' earned is RARELY worth more than the revenue-percentage you forfeit. There isn't a single music library or 'thumbnail help' worth 30% of income. Which is why it's important to negotiate, and figure out the best deal for your channel.
I've signed on to MCNs in the past because the contract WAS FAVORABLE TO ME. Most of the 'default' options Sugi lists in his shitty article are not. They are overtly predatory, and offer few tangible benefits or guarantees to their partners.

No your pathetic
**you're*
you had 10 years to work on a channel
That's actually the entire reason for the low-conversion rate in the first place: my channel's age. All 2006-channels are feeling similar affects. Again, not sure how my own personal viewership is relevant to a conversation about MCNs in the fucking slightest, but keep digging your hole deeper.
Owning a CMS-level account is not a conflict of interest here. Do you even understand what that concept means? Hahah, obviously not. If anything, it gives me a more unique and knowledable perspective on the situation, as I'm familiar with the toolset and advantages of both environments.
its not like i have referral links to all networks out there
What?! Hahahah! You really are fucking dumb, aren't you? I don't care if it's one link or twenty. You are advocating the benefits of MCNs so you can personally benefit from someone's sign-up - that is the TEXTBOOK definition of a conflict of interest, you obtuse fool.
* conflict of interest noun
* a situation in which a person is in a position to derive personal benefit from actions or decisions made in their official capacity.*

Your just autistic liberal cuck
I catch you in an obvious conflict of interest (disclosed, or otherwise) - and your immature response is to resort to poorly-spelled, shitty 4-chan inspired character attacks? Wow, you really are pathetic.

yes but that ability is not available for a person who is signed with Adsense.
But it DOES exist! Which proves your "*many things a partner can't do*" claim wrong!
Referral business is very lucrative lets just say that.
**AND THERE IT IS!**
Your entire article, and every opinion you've shared on MCNs are disqualified due to this blatant conflict of interest. Of course *you* are in favor of these predatory, short-form contracts - because *you're* benefiting from them.
Fuck you, and your shit advice.

Damn, you're annoying.
I'm just saying - *include a disclaimer*. Your article is factually untrue by omission. I don't care if it's 'anecdotal' or not - it still proves your article is missing information. **Telling younger/smaller channels to blindly accept predatory contracts is extremely dangerous** .

How/why have you been signed to over 20? Do you manage 20+ separate channels, or have you only signed-on to 1-month terms? The MCN model has only been around since 2010.
And I knew about the "simple fact" about claiming videos. But it's also an ability I have - all by myself, without the help of any revenue-sharing or large MCNs.

The fact that you're advocating a channel with only 100 subs to join a network is awful advice. If you don't have any power to negotiate, maybe it's a sign you shouldn't be making a deal at all?
Again though: you seem completely oblivious to my chief criticism -- the article does not mention who you're targeting this advice towards. Just a short prologue explaining, "*Your mileage may vary - these number are only averages (that smaller channels might expect to see in a default contract). Larger channels can, and likely should negotiate for more favorable deals.*" THAT'S ALL!
Gotta apply the practices in the Playbook too. Important not to ignore that.

**Create good content, consistently.**
Also, read the YouTube Playbook, and apply its practices.
"*other guys got away with it*" has NEVER been a viable legal defense, FYI.

While I understand why he brought it up, that doesn't make it "fair", just understandable.
You're right though - I have over a decade of experience, and I'd like to think that does make me an authority on YouTube. Not sure how one of my channel's lower-than-average 'conversion rate' somehow disqualifies the 10+ years of knowledge and experience I've gained. If this was a discussion on viewer-retention, or how to grow a channel in its 11th-year, sure - you'd have an argument there as to why my opinion is disqualifying.
**But we're talking about MCNs**. And therefore, it isn't a "fair point" - it's just an ad hominem attack.

lol @ the mcn expert tag
Hahah, my thoughts exactly. Pretty sure this guy doesn't even know the difference between an affiliate or managed channel.

who fail to look from perspective the benefits of joining a MCN.
Besides signing bonuses - name one concrete "benefit" creators can't get on their own without forfieting a percentage of their monthly revenue?
And this isn't being 'skeptical" about "anecdotes". I RUN A NETWORK. I've been in this space for over a decade, and have spoken with the heads of at least a dozen MCNs -- I know their contracts, I know how they work. I have personally been signed to three of them.
**You're dismissing proven experience because you disagree with my conclusions, and that's just irresponsible.**

Fair point about Jon's conversation rate.
Haha, no it wasn't. Bad-mouthing my first-week viewership on one of my network's 10 channels isn't relevant to this discussion in the slightest. It was a pointless character attack, not a "fair point".
